Reviews.Content: Cheap and cheerful. We stayed in a double room, which was big enough for a bed and standing room next to the bed. We were travelling light, so it was fine. We only used the room to sleep, we were out and about the rest of the time.The room was smallllllll and a bit stuffy, but it was cleaned daily, there were shared toilet and shower facilities, which is fine in theory but we were fighting for access with a massive high school group who were also on our floor. Breakfast downstairs was simple but cheap, unlimited coffee/tea refills and toast once you'd paid your small fee. Free wireless access downstairs was also a big bonus, and something we really appreciated.It's located close to a few subway stations, and fairly centrally placed, not far from the Imperial Palace East Gardens. Staff are really friendly, and everyone speaks English and Japanese. Lots of information about Tokyo is available at the desk and the staff were happy to help out.We were happy with the place, particularly for the price, and would probably stay again.
Reviews.Author: femcastra

Reviews.Content: Simple and functional option for travellers on a budget Sakura Hotel offers basic accommodation with low rates and a great location. You get what you pay for, however. The rooms are clean, but very small (only fits a bed and enough room to walk past it), even for Japan. Toilets and showers are shared, which is not so bad as they were cleaned daily. The wash basins are right out in the corridor, however. It was pretty weird to stand there brushing one鈥檚 teeth right next to another guest. Towels are not included but can be rented (almost for free, merely 100 yen per towel).We chose Sakura Hotel because it is called a hotel and I dislike hostels. It felt much more like a hostel than a hotel however, so the name is rather misleading. For a hostel, it was ok.The staff speaks English, and is really helpful and service minded. They seemed slightly undermanned at times though. There is a caf茅/bar, but it was unmanned most of the time, which meant that you鈥檇 have to call for the person at the front desk to come and take your order. He/she would have to leave the front desk (possibly with people waiting in line) just to make your cappuccino or whatever. Felt kind of weird. There is a basic breakfast served in the morning (included in the price if you stay in a single room, otherwise costing a mere 315 yen). It is very basic (tea/coffee and toast), but it is nice to get something before going out sightseeing. The location of the hotel is excellent in terms of transportation. Although there is not much happening in the Jimbocho area, the hotel is only a few minutes' walk from Jimbocho station, from which you can easily get to more interesting neighborhoods. The subway system is easy to understand. Just make sure to get a pasmo card, and you won鈥檛 have to worry about transfers and costs. All in all, Sakura Hotel is a fine place to stay if you are on a tight budget and don鈥檛 mind staying at a hostel. For my own part, if I had known how low prices actually were in Tokyo, I would have paid up to stay at a real hotel instead.
Reviews.Author: arevan_1

Reviews.Content: Smelly, Sweaty Locker       This was the room we got...not the one we wanted. It looks bigger in the picture than it was.
Reviews.Author: sexymixer

Reviews.Content: Good location, poor hygiene standards Good price and location but unfortunately there is quite a serious bed bug problem. For this reason alone I would not stay here again or recommend it.
Reviews.Author: jakesid

Reviews.Content: basement The dorms are in the basement, one female dorm and one male dorm. No windows, a bit damp. It was smelly when you first enter the dorm, but after you turn on the air-conditioner for a while, it was OK. Curtains for beds were shown in their website, but there was none, only hooks where curtains used to be (if ever).
Reviews.Author: taikoouser

Reviews.Content: A nice little haven in busy Tokyo I stayed 6 nights in Sakura Hotel by myself. It was very difficult for me to pick a hotel as Tokyo is such an enourmous place but I liked Sakura's website and the price was right for a budget traveler like myself.I arrived Tokyo by train from Nagoya, and getting around first with a big backbag in July heat in rush hour Tokyo was rather challenging. Despite of the instructions I had printed out (which were not very specific as I trusted I could find the place as it was close to the station) I had major difficulties finding Sakura at first. I managed to get to the Jimbocho metro station and although Sakura was very close to it, I almost gave up and slept on the street instead :) The Japanese aroud either knew nothing, spoke no English or were pointing at all different directions!Anyway after finding Sakura I had a friendly welcome and got my room. It was teeny tiny but I didn't anticipate spending much time there anyway. There was just enough room for a single bed and walking past it. The room also had tv. The window was covered because of some construction they were making so I saw no light at all. It felt like staying in a closet but I didn't mind too much although I would have appreciated some daylight. I got a hair drier from the desk, and the air conditioning worked well. In July in Tokyo air condition is a must... The showers and bathrooms were shared and in the same floor. They were always clean and nice. The room had a rope and slippers so you could just put them on going to shower. Breakfast included to the private room rate and Sakura had a nice and often busy cafe-bar downstairs to have it. Basically it was toast and coffee, but that was good enough and it is always nice to get something before leaving. There was also internet but using it was very expensive.Overall, I had a pleasant stay in Sakura. It was far from luxury but for a little budjet hotel it did its job well. As a solo traveler I felt safe, comfortable and welcome. I would recommend Sakura to travelers like myself that need a modest and reasonably priced place.
Reviews.Author: miyu_princess

Reviews.Content: clean and simple The Sakura Hotel, Jimbocho is an excellent budget hotel. It is really cheap for Tokyo and although the rooms are quite small they are functional and spotlessly clean. The bed size wasn't really a problem for us and we're quite tall.The hotel staff were friendly and all seemed to have good English, which is handy. The front desk is manned 24 hours and the cafe is 24 hours but I didn't observe anyone using it really late at night apart from using the internet.There's a few computers for internet use, the charge is 锟?00 per 10 minutes which isn't great (compared to the fantastic internet cafe prices in Tokyo) but fine if you just want to check your email.The showers and toilet facilities are shared which I was apprehensive about at first but there were never any problems with this and they were cleaned daily. Good water pressure in the showers. Towel hire is 锟?00 which I didn't think was very good since it is called a hotel rather than a hostel, I feel that if you have a private room, with the extra you're paying compared to the dormitories you really could do with getting a couple of towels included.Breakfast was 锟?15 per person but all you get is toast. There's a loaf of bread and a toaster and little packets of butter and jam. There's a large selection of tea which is included as breakfast and also packets of dried soup granules. The breakfast wasn't BAD as such but not really worth paying for. Would be fine if it was complimentary.Good location right next to the Jimbocho subway line where you can get to anywhere you want to in Tokyo once you work out the subway system! If you stand around any station looking confused then you're basically guaranteed to have someone try to help you and then you'll figure out what you're doing. God bless the person that decided to put the subway lines in romaji as well as kanji!Overall this was a nice place to stay on a budget. If what you want is a clean and cosy room for the night then that's what you get. I would stay here again because it was clean and the price was good.
Reviews.Author: mittencats

Reviews.Content: Wonderful, simply marvelous! Hello!Having stayed at Sakura Hotel on numerous occasions I can recommend it to travelers the world over! The place is cheaper than the ladies of Shinjuku, and that's pretty cheap for Tokyo! The rooms are clean with a daily wake up call by their friendly cleaning staff who barge into your room unannounced while you are lying naked in your bed or in an intimate moment with a lady friend, I am a ladies' man after all! The desk staff are always friendly. Dealing with your problems with a smile and no thanks necessary. A Continental Breakfast (which I believe is Japanese for Toast and orange juice) is provided in the mornings to guests. PROTIP: The staff don't check if you're staying at the hotel, so if you're staying at the Hilton or Mandarin Oriental and feel like a free breakfast stop by, no one will notice! Toilet and shower facilities are shared and if you are a voyeur this hotel will be ideal as there are windows on the toilet doors that, if you press against hard enough, will allow you to see what's going on inside! They are cleaned daily and always in pristine condition.TVs are provided in the rooms with pay TV available from vending machines on the floors. The channels that this gives you is some sport and a whole load of pornography, which is nice.All in all I would stay at the Sakura Hotel everytime I come to Japan! Well done.
Reviews.Author: KennethKorda

Reviews.Content: Great location and prices Great budget hotel in a central location in Tokyo. Rooms cover anything from singles to group dorms and everything is very clean and neat. Decent showers, English speaking staff and no curfew. There's also free tea and breakfast. A good base to explore the city.
Reviews.Author: aciddave

Reviews.Content: Neat, cheap, great location My husband and I spent a great week staying at the Sakura Hotel in Tokyo. It's great value for money in Tokyo terms. Be cautious if you like a lot of space though, because the rooms are very compact. The staff are very friendly, the rooms and shared bathrooms were clean and tidy, and the location is fantastic - it's in the heart of the Jimbocho book district, only a couple minutes walk from the subway, from where you're only another couple of minutes from Shibuya, Shinjuku and Harajuku. I'd definitely stay here again.
Reviews.Author: pinkhoshi

Reviews.Content: Great cheap place! This place is just what a budget traveller to Tokyo needs. Its cheap, the rooms are basic but perfect for the traveller, and the recepetion desk in manned 24 hours with the most helpful people. Specifically Nori who gave us great advice on our stay in Tokyo. Its location in Jimbocho is great too as you are close to the subway and only a few stops to all the attractions. I give it a double thumbs up.
Reviews.Author: wazzahozza

Reviews.Content: Sakura Hostel does it better than the hotel We stayed here for our last night in Japan. The staff was very helpful and accomodated us for an early check in. They were also very helpful with directions and for information.The room was spacious, but stank of stale smoke. Beds were comfortable, 4 bunks in a private room. Bedding was included but if you want a towel its 100 Yen extra.It felt like we were in a hostel or a college dorm rather than a hotel.This chain also does a hostel which we stayed at the week previous and was FAR superior and cheaper.
Reviews.Author: kittenwithawhip

Reviews.Content: Friendly, helpful staff What I was most impressed about this hotel was the friendly staff who always went beyond their duties to make my stay as wonderful as possible. They were most helpful with directions, and general information, and even printed out a map from the internet for us! This is much more than I expected from any hotel front staff, esp. having stayed in many hotels in Europe.However, the downside is that the room we had was really small! I could barely walk with a suitcase on the floor! We had to prop the suitcase up every time we're in the room, just so we can walk around the room. But the rate was cheap, and I could live with a small room, only needing it to sleep.The bathrooms were clean and tidy.The hotel is only a short walk to the train station (Jimbocho - if I remember correctly).Overall I would recommend this hotel for any budget-conscious traveller needing a clean room for a night, wiht the added bonus of extra friendly staff.
Reviews.Author: Cherryblossum

Reviews.Content: Cheap place to stay in Tokyo Cheap for Tokyo and fully acceptable. But just a place to stay. You cannot spend time in the little room, but can hang out in the cafe downstairs. It is clean and not too hard to find. Tiny rooms with shared bathrooms. Staff are friendly and speak English. I had no problems at all.
Reviews.Author: travellevret
